content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a large section of tissue, likely a colorectal resection. A significant portion is occupied by a deeply basophilic (purple) mass, suggestive of a tumor. The upper portion shows layered colonic wall architecture. Several distinct, ovoid, and basophilic structures are present, consistent with lymph nodes (I can count at least 5-6). The overall impression is a large, infiltrative colorectal carcinoma with associated regional lymph nodes that need to be evaluated for metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is placed within the main body of the primary tumor. I would zoom into this area to confirm the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma and to assess its histological features, such as the architectural pattern (gland formation), nuclear grade, and presence of necrosis. This characterization is crucial for determining the tumor grade, which is an important prognostic factor. This specific area appears to be representative of the tumor's overall morphology, showing densely packed glandular structures. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows malignant glands with a complex, back-to-back, and cribriform architecture. The neoplastic cells are columnar with elongated, hyperchromatic, and pseudostratified nuclei, demonstrating significant atypia. There is a prominent desmoplastic stromal response (the pink fibrous tissue between the glands) with an associated inflammatory infiltrate. My impression is that this is a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma.
